newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil millers want wheat exempt from import rules.
newsitem.headline: Brazil millers want wheat exempt from import rules.

text.p: Brazilian millers want the government to exclude wheat from new measures restricting import financing because they say it is a necessary foodstuff, said the Brazilian Association of Wheat Industries (Abitrigo).
"I am asking that, at least, wheat be excluded," said Abitrigo president Antenor Barros Leal.

Brazil last week announced restrictions on import financing of under a year, with the aim of preventing importers from benefiting from low international interest rates. The rules apply to goods shipped after March 31.
Abitrigo has sent a letter to the government requesting wheat be exempt from the measures, but it has not received a reply yet, Leal said.
"The problem is in changing import rules for a product which we cannot stop importing. You can stop importing caviar and cars, but not wheat," he said.
Currently, the average financing period for wheat imports is 180 days at an interest rate of eight percent.

Under the new rules, importers have to pay for their foreign currency the day they pick up their merchandise from customs. This could create cash-flow problems for some millers whose import programmes are not flexible, Abitrigo said. Brazil's partners in the Mercosur trade union -- Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay -- have also protested. They say they should be excluded from the measure, seen as a first step to curb Brazil's burgeoning trade deficit which hit $5.5 billion in 1996. Leal said he had contacted the Argentine government and had been told Argentina would also ask for wheat to be excluded.
Brazil imported 5.75 million tonnes of wheat in the 1996/97 harvest year, according to independent consultants Safras e Mercado. Of this, between 4.5 and five million tonnes was from Argentina.
